subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etyl}}
[[File:Yanzhou Museum 2015.08.13 15-15-43.jpg|thumb|100px|A {{zh-l|*瓮}} from the {{w|Longshan culture}} (also called Black Pottery Culture) {{defdate|3000 – 1900 BC}}.]]

The traditional interpretation as given by ''{{w|Han Feizi}}'' is that {{lang|zh|公}} is a compound of {{zh-l|*八}} (= {{zh-l|*背|to deviate; opposite}}) and {{zh-l|*厶}} (original form of {{zh-l|*私|individual; private}}), i.e. the opposite of “individual”; public. This theory is supported by Sun Yirang and Qiang Kaiyun, despite the somewhat different shape of the top component from {{lang|zh|厶}}.

This is disputed in modern times by Gao Hongjin, who thinks that the {{lang|zh|八}} on top stands for {{zh-l|*分|to divide; to distribute}} and the bottom round component of {{zh-l|*口}} symbolises the general object. {{lang|zh|公}} thus represents “equally dividing resources so that they are '''communal'''”.

Another theory put forth by Zhu Fangpu is that {{lang|zh|公}} is a {{liushu|p|nocap=1}}, being the original form of {{och-l|瓮|a wide-mouthed round-bottomed [[jar]]}}, and later borrowed for the meaning of “public”.

subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
;"fair, impartial, public"
: From {{der|zh|sit}}, cognate with {{cog|bo|tr=guṅ.mo|t=middle}}, considering that "middle" is often semantically associated with "balance" ({{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}).

;"highest-ranking nobility title, duke"
:Possibly from {{der|zh|aav}}, compare {{cog|km|ឡូញ||chief}} and {{m|km|tr=klooɲ||t=higher-ranking dignitary than louñ}}. Compare also {{cog|tai-pro|*luŋᴬ||parent's older brother}}, whence {{cog|th|ลุง}} which is also borrowed from {{w|Proto-Austroasiatic language|Mon-Khmer}}. {{cog|bo|tr=khoṅ}} ~ {{m|bo|tr=goṅ}} "final syllable in dignataries' name" may be borrowed from Chinese ([[ibid.]]).
